body: Shouldn't this subclass the global modifier?
Why should it?

Because you are just duplicating some logic.
Especially the info property, but perhaps that is not best.

> Shouldn't this subclass the global modifier?
> Because you are just duplicating some logic.
> Especially the info property, but perhaps that is not best.

Okay, will try that. Then this depends on https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7863 now.

I don't like being the party pooper all the time, but I think that this use case (thunder/lighting) would be much better served by exposing a Lua API to #7863.  That would then allow mappers to also do other things such as day/night cycles, turning the weather on/off, or 70's disco mode.
When I saw how day/night-cycling is done in Tiberian Sun with triggers that also came to my mind. Traits are a bit simpler to use. We could have both ways to set them up.

Traits are simple to use, but limited for this purpose.  This trait is only really useable for the one or two maps that might want to feature a thunderstorm as a gimmick.  The TS ion storm works rather differently.

I merged https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7871 and https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7863 in here as this seems to be the last one of them getting merged though not for technical reasons (GlobalPaletteModifier does not share enough logic to justify sub-classing), but to add a test case (Fort Lonestar) here. All those traits work together to create the atmosphere.
Also tried to please the reviewers a bit.
I think the lightnings need to be nerfed. Complete white is too much.
Also needs a rebase.
Can you review and merge #7871 first?
Rebased and reworked the implementation based on the negative feedback. The `Thunder` trait has been removed. Everything is triggered via the Lua API now.
I refactored this further by merging my FlashPaletteEffect with NukePaletteEffect eliminating redundancy and making the flash effect smoother by not going for 100% color replacement.

This hasn't really addressed my core comment, which is that we don't need (or IMO want) a dedicated trait for flashing the screen.  By exposing a Lua API for `GlobalLightingPaletteEffect` you allow mappers to implement any kind of lighting changes they can think of (including lightning and day / night cycles)  without requiring a bunch of overly specific traits.

I tried that at first, but it did not work at all. Our Lua API does not support float values (which is the first problem) and then you need to work with cache and reset the old values which is over-complicating things. You also won't get the quick fade which is important here. The Lua API for `GlobalLightingPaletteEffect` is another pull request with the use-case day/night cycle.
I had to rebase this.

It crashes for me when using the lua function more than once.
Example script:

``` lua
    Palette.FlashEffect(25)

    Trigger.AfterDelay(DateTime.Seconds(2), function()
        Palette.FlashEffect(25)
    end)
```

Gives me:

``` Exception
Red Alert Mod at Version {DEV_VERSION}
Operating System: Windows (Microsoft Windows NT 6.2.9200.0)
Runtime Version: .NET CLR 4.0.30319.34209
Exception of type `System.ArgumentException`: A value of -1 is invalid for red. Red must be greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to 255.
(Der Wert -1 ist für red ungültig. red muss größer als oder gleich 0 und kleiner als oder gleich 255 sein.)
   at System.Drawing.Color.CheckByte(Int32 value, String name)
   at System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb(Int32 alpha, Int32 red, Int32 green, Int32 blue)
   at OpenRA.Graphics.Util.PremultipliedColorLerp(Single t, Color c1, Color c2) in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Graphics\Util.cs:Line 128.
   at OpenRA.Mods.Common.Traits.FlashPaletteEffect.AdjustPalette(IReadOnlyDictionary`2 palettes)
   at OpenRA.Graphics.HardwarePalette.ApplyModifiers(IEnumerable`1 paletteMods) in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Graphics\HardwarePalette.cs:Line 114.
   at OpenRA.Graphics.WorldRenderer.RefreshPalette() in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Graphics\WorldRenderer.cs:Line 228.
   at OpenRA.Graphics.WorldRenderer.Draw() in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Graphics\WorldRenderer.cs:Line 129.
   at OpenRA.Game.RenderTick() in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Game.cs:Line 497.
   at OpenRA.Game.Loop() in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Game.cs:Line 619.
   at OpenRA.Game.Run() in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Game.cs:Line 637.
   at OpenRA.Program.Run(String[] args) in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Support\Program.cs:Line 111.
   at OpenRA.Program.Main(String[] args) in \OpenRA\OpenRA.Game\Support\Program.cs:Line 39.

```
Rebased and added a safeguard against that crash.

"Battlecontrol terminated" is now cut when leaving a map.

I'm also still able to reproduce https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7872#issuecomment-109759334.
I may need your full example script, because I am not able to reproduce with my latest changes.

> "Battlecontrol terminated" is now cut when leaving a map.

Fixed by putting the stop sound into world dispose like https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8568.
The overall implementation looks fine, but we'll need to resolve the audio situation (which i've completely lost track of) before merging. :+1: after the inline comments are resolved.
Rebased and applied the requested changes.
Needs a rebase again.
Rebased and updated.
Looks good overall. :+1: once we've decided on a name for the API.
Renamed things.
[Changelog](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/wiki/Changelog-%28bleed%29/_compare/01970a08428e55e16c32010f0668b5170f4735ef%5E...01970a08428e55e16c32010f0668b5170f4735ef)
